posts.name: M
posts.cooked: I am currently the only team programmer and electrical person, and we are a returning team with a blank slate what have CIMs and TalonSRX that we are going to use for a one-stage elevator how do I use them, and how would I program a elevator with those electronics (do I need other electronics such as sensors)?

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked:
It depends how you are driving the elevator, but you will want some form of feedback. Relative encoders can be directly connected into the talon srx using encoder breakout boards Talon SRX Encoder Breakout Board – CTR Electronics

Or the magnetic srx encoder (will require a little extra work to get working on a single cim without a versa planetary gearbox) SRX Mag Encoder – CTR Electronics

Both above would connect directly to the data port of the SRX with a gadgeteer cable

Any digital quadrature encoder will work here. Then you can use the Talon SRX in position mode directly. You would create a home where the elevator starts every match. From there the relative encoder can track rotations as the elevator driving mechanisms axle rotates. You can move to a setpoint encoder position using tuned PID and you should be set.

Primer on Closed-loop: Talon SRX and Victor SPX supports a variety of closed-loop modes including position closed-loop, velocity closed-loop, Motion Profiling, and Motion Magic. Talon SRX additiona...

link_counts.title: Motor Controller Closed Loop — Phoenix documentation
Talon SRX Encoder Breakout Board – CTR Electronics

posts.name: M
posts.cooked: What do you mean by driving the elevator?

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked:
There are several types of elevators (cascading or not) and ways to drive their motion up and down. Most common is a motor with gearbox at the bottom that either revolves a winch and cable, or sprocket/chain/belt/pulley. As it pulls the cable right around the winch the stages of the elevator are pulled up against gravity. Then you release tension by rotating the motor the opposite direction and let gravity pull them back down.

This is a playlist of elevator examples and you’ll see there is a large variety of ways to power their motion: https://youtube.com/playlist?list=PLYcmd5xMhOBAE6gwe2u9mR3wP7Yp861C3&si=ptOqqJ7rDnnulqK6

In the end it’s usually one or two motors in a gearbox spinning some axle you can put an encoder on. You can measure how many counts of the encoder equates to a linear distance the elevator travels up or down.

posts.name: M
posts.cooked: We are going to run a garage door style gear and chain with one CIM motor and having and axle go through both sides gear and chain

posts.name: M
posts.cooked: Gear box is currently undecided

posts.name: Aidan McMaster
posts.cooked: it would probably be easiest for you to just incorporate limit switches at the top and bottom of the elevator (they can be dio inputs on the rio). And your drivers will just manually jog the elevator

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked:
If you go this route get extremely durable ones, and mount them where they are not likely to get smashed by accident.

If you do any ‘automatic’ routines with only limit switches, add timeouts to the commands. If the switch is damaged or the wire becomes disconnected from the Rio your mechanism may run continuously destroying the mechanism from severe overrun.

You can also wire limit switches directly to the SRX for a shorted wire path and configure them to automatically stop motor power in one direction or the other.

posts.name: M
posts.cooked: What is the automatic routine, timeouts? also is there another way to sensors or switches? We are planning to do L 123 and maybe 4.

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked:
Some teams will create ‘automated’ commands or routines to move the mechanism (subsystem) to a set position (L1, L2, etc) from a button press. Instead of manually adjusting the height up and down til it looks right, just go to the exact position.

This is an example from another team in 2019 FRC-2019/src/main/java/frc/subsystem/Elevator.java at master · FRC3476/FRC-2019 · GitHub

Things have changed a little since then, but it shows using setpoints, homing and some other good practices like the timeouts.

If you trigger one of these commands, but without a timeout it will try to run until it reaches the position. This could never happen either because the exact count to stop at is too hard to reach, or the motor was configured wrong so it’s driving the wrong way, etc. in all of these cases you want the system to shutdown after X time if it didn’t complete itself normally.

Mako:

also is there another way to sensors or switches

Beyond encoders or limit switches directly wired to the SRX, you can use distance sensors to measure how far the traveling stage (gantry) is from the bottom of the elevator. Sensors like the CanRange or LaserCan or TOF (Time of Flight) can give exact distance measurements. Instead of using encoder counts you use that measurement for position mode control. This is a newer concept where there may not be lots of examples already. I would not suggest this route, unless you have successfully built an elevator before.

Final sensor option i can think of is hall effect limit switches instead of physical contact styles. Hall Effect Sensor — AndyMark

One of the most common sensing tasks on a robot is detecting when an object (be it a mechanism, game piece, or field element) is within a certain distance of a known point on the robot. This type o...

Sometimes these are called prox switches. You attach a magnet on the moving portion and put the hall effect sensors in a stationary position. Whenever the magnet is lined up with the sensor (proximity based) it will send a signal. You can react to these just like physical limit switches to stop moving the motor.

link_counts.title: Proximity Switches - Hardware — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: M
posts.cooked: We were planning on doing something like this because we figured that fiddling around with guessing the elevator height 1 takes too much time 2 is inaccurate.

posts.name: M
posts.cooked: So I found a bag of limit switches so I will be running those how would I use them with the Talon’s? @Soren_1 @AluminumMagikarp

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked:
There’s a few ways to use them either directly, or indirectly to control the SRX motor controllers.

In the Talon SRX user guide, pages 20 and 21 show how to wire it to the onboard data port directly. Usually you use a breakout board like the ones used for encoders (they work for the limit switches too). Below is a screenshot of the forward switch wiring, reverse is similar.

Screenshot_20250211_080254_Adobe Acrobat 970×884 156 KB

Screenshot_20250211_080254_Adobe Acrobat 970×884 156 KB

Screenshot_20250211_080254_Adobe Acrobat 970×884 156 KB

When you are directly wired through the SRX you will not need to nessecarily add additional programming (depending on the switch state NO or NC). When the limit switch is triggered and wired directly, it stops the motor automatically.

At this point all Talon and Victors should appear in Tuner with up to date firmware. The next goal is to drive the motor controller manually. This is done to confirm/test: Motor and motor wiring, T...

If you don’t want to wire it directly to the SRX you can instead go to the RoboRios DIO pins: Proximity Switches - Hardware — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

If you go through the RoboRio you will need to monitor the switch yourself and then stop the motor when needed.

posts.name: H
posts.cooked:
Looks like @kingc95 got to it!

Definitely support wiring straight to the motor controller - you may need a breakout board though to make the wiring easier.

Doing an automated routine with a CIM motor will be a little harder than a brushless motor as it does not have an integrated encoder, therefore you’d need to wire an encoder up to the motor controller to use the position control mode. Tune slowly, and use software tools like Phoenix Tuner to get you there, rather than trying to redeploy code all the time.

If you can’t do this, it is possible to run “automatic” type methods with a bunch of limit switches but as others have said, this is risky. It amounts to “run motor until this limit switch is depressed”, which if bent/broken/etc, will cause the motor to run uncontrollably and likely damage the motor controller, motor or physical components. You also need gearing or a recurring command to hold the arm roughly in place. Easier to do just L4 with this as “run to the top” is easy. “run to some intermediate position” is much harder.

If you want to do this, Top and Bottom mechanical limits to motor controller to get the automatic cutoff, then rest to roborio. Remember they are forward and reverse direction of travel per the motor, so depending on your design “up” may be “reverse”

Depending on the strengths of your team, combining a limit switch approach with a mechanical brake or stopping mechanism could be easier.

Also just a random pro-tip from my team, if these are the lever-arm type switches…make sure they’re side-along mounted and not used as impact switches. They won’t survive if you do. (Source: destroyed them and had to drop in to hard-manual in our first practice match, lol)
